references: We have summarized the investigation work based on different implementation methods of shilling attacks and the required knowledge for executing shilling attacks. Please refer to Table I for the details.

To address the aforementioned issues, we propose an adversarial robustness evaluation library named ShillingREC, which supports various attack modes and recommendation tasks. The overall framework of ShillingREC is illustrated in Figure 6. ShillingREC can flexibly design attack modes based on different data types and recommendation task types. Specifically, as shown in Table I, we categorize shilling attacks into attacks on rating data and attacks on implicit feedback data. For attacks on rating data, we evaluate them on rating prediction tasks and ranking tasks based on pointwise optimization strategies. For attacks on implicit feedback data, we evaluate them on ranking tasks based on pairwise optimization strategies. Moreover, ShillingREC supports multiple commonly used datasets and is easily extensible. Integrates well-designed execution processes and comprehensive persistence strategies for data preprocessing, poisoning attacks, and recommendation model training.

references: In order to address the aforementioned issues concerning various types of recommender system attacks and existing defense strategies against such attacks, we aim to establish a unified evaluation framework to systematically assess them. This approach facilitates the analysis of the characteristics and applicability of different methods and provides a fair competition platform for various attack and defense techniques. To tackle this challenge, we conducted an investigation on open-source recommender system frameworks, as shown in Table IV. This investigation includes evaluation frameworks tailored for recommendation tasks, as well as those designed specifically to assess recommender system attacks. While several evaluation frameworks for attack, such as RecAd [90] and ARLib [90] and ARLib [91], already exist, RecAd primarily targets attacks on rating data, lacking adaptation for implicit feedback data. In contrast, ARLib is designed for implicit feedback data, converting some rating data-based attack methods to attacks on implicit feedback data and evaluating them in ranking tasks. However, this setting may not be equitable for certain attack methods designed for rating data. [91], already exist, RecAd primarily targets attacks on rating data, lacking adaptation for implicit feedback data. In contrast, ARLib is designed for implicit feedback data, converting some rating data-based attack methods to attacks on implicit feedback data and evaluating them in ranking tasks. However, this setting may not be equitable for certain attack methods designed for rating data.

references: For implicit feedback data, we employed four adversarial attack methods: RandomAttack, BandwagonAttack, AUSH, and RevAdv, to assess the recommender system’s performance on recommending the target item. Evaluation metrics including NDCG and HitRatio were utilized. The experimental setup is as follows: for each attack method, identical attack parameters were set, specifically, the attacker size was set to 20% of the total number of users in the training dataset; the target item number was set to 0.5% of the attacker size, with randomly selected items as targets, and the filler item size was set to the dataset’s average. The victim models employed were MF, NewMF, LightGCN, and SGL, with pairwise optimization strategies utilized to enhance victim model robustness. Experimental results are presented in Table V.

references: To evaluate the capability of the Shilling attack against explicit feedback data, we conducted experiments using four attack models: Random Attack, Average Attack, Love/Hate Attack, and AUSH. We compared the performance differences of the recommender system rating prediction task before and after the attacks. The experimental setup is as follows: we selected three commonly used rating datasets in the recommender system domain, namely ML-100k, ML-1M, and CiaoDVD, for experimentation. For different attack methods, we set the same attack parameters. Specifically, the attacker size was set to 20% of the total number of users in the training dataset; the target item number was set to one third of the attacker size, with popular items selected as targets, and the filler item size was set to the dataset’s average. The victim model used was the classic NeuMF model, and we evaluated the performance of the NeuMF model on the rating prediction task. The specific experimental results are shown in Table VI.

references: To evaluate the robustness of the recommendation models, we selected AUSH as the attack model and the MF, NeuMF, LightGCN and SGL models as the victim models. We compared the performance of these three models in the rating prediction task under attack scenarios on the ML-100k, ML-1M and CiaoDVD datasets. We utilized MAE and RMSE as evaluation metrics. The specific experimental results are presented in Table VII.
